title: Capitals
family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Square Capitals
children.desc: Angular, good for chisel-writing because very square, also used for high quality manuscripts.
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Rustic Capitals
children.desc: Similar to Square Capitals, easier to write with a reed pen or quill because more fluid lines are used. Some instances of Rustic Capitals predate Square Capitals.
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Rustic Capitals in Stone
children.desc: Scriptura Actuaria
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Old Roman Cursive
children.desc: Used for correspondence, administrative purposes, every day writing, etc. Fragmented letter forms, high fluidity (ability to be written quickly).
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Literary Cursive
children.desc: Variant of Old Roman Cursive. More formal.
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: New Roman Cursive
children.desc: Result of a reform of cursive scripts from s. iii<sup>ex</sup> – s. iv<sup>in</sup>. Quicker, loops introduced, influence on later Half Uncial.)
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Merovingian Chancery
children.desc: Elongated ascenders and descenders (no loops), spider-like, attenuation, and compression.
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Ravenna Chancery
children.desc: Elegance and formality, ligatures and loops (foot-loop abbreviation), exaggerated letter forms.
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Visigothic Miniscule
children.desc: Kept in Spain until s. xii.
children.family: National Hands (Sub-Roman Hands) (s. v and s. vi - s. viii<sup>ex</sup> and s. ix)

children.title: Uncial (Littera Uncialis)
children.desc: A combination of Old Roman Cursive, Greek Uncial (especially BR Uncial), and Literary Cursive, Littera Uncialis is characterized by its round letter forms and typically has very few abbreviations (typically the only abbreviations used are for nomina sacra).
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Merovingian Uncial
children.desc: Characterized by flat head of ascender on D, hook on head of T, clowed bow E, sharp diagonal stroke on Y, etc.
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Half Uncial
children.desc: More rapid than Uncial, smaller strokes, straight pen, upright ductus.
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Miniscule Scripts
children.desc: Quattrolinear Book Scripts
children.family: National Hands (Sub-Roman Hands) (s. v and s. vi - s. viii<sup>ex</sup> and s. ix)

children.title: Corbie AB Miniscule
children.desc: Regularity of script, characteristic a and b, z-shaped abbreviation bars, use of the punctus interrogativus, etc.
children.family: National Hands (Sub-Roman Hands) (s. v and s. vi - s. viii<sup>ex</sup> and s. ix)

children.title: Luxeuil Miniscule
children.desc: Erratic ductus (rounded and angular/broken forms are both used), lengthening, clubbed-look of ascenders and descenders.
children.family: National Hands (Sub-Roman Hands) (s. v and s. vi - s. viii<sup>ex</sup> and s. ix)

children.title: German Miniscule
children.desc: Many ligatures, angular/flat-headed Half-Uncial G, etc.
children.family: National Hands (Sub-Roman Hands) (s. v and s. vi - s. viii<sup>ex</sup> and s. ix)

children.title: Beneventan Miniscule
children.desc: Middle 8th-century, breadth, roundness, formal, regular, etc.
children.family: National Hands (Sub-Roman Hands) (s. v and s. vi - s. viii<sup>ex</sup> and s. ix)

children.title: Cursive Half Uncial (Quarter Uncial)
children.desc: Rapid form of Half Uncial. Lots of ligatures. Is the foundation for Insular Scripts. Introduced into Ireland around s. vi<sup>ex</sup>.
children.family: Roman System of Scripts (31 BC - 14 AD)

children.title: Formal book script
children.desc: Like Roman Half-Uncial, but not as formal.
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Insular Cursive Miniscule (Cursiva)
children.desc: Ligatures and loops, detailed calligraphy distorts letter forms, detailed, tends to point, many abbreviations.
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Insular Set Miniscule (Cursiva Formata)
children.desc: Written with a slanted pen, several cursive letter forms, round D and S.
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Insular Pointed Cursive Miniscule (from the s. ix<sup>1</sup>)
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Anglo-Saxon Pointed Miniscule (s. ix<sup>ex</sup>)
children.desc: Elegant, pointed, backs of bows broken, etc.
children.family: Anglo-Saxon Scripts

children.title: Anglo-Saxon Square Miniscule
children.desc: Differs from the Anglo-Saxon Pointed Miniscule in that it is square-looking. Formal and regular ductus, extra stroke on several backs of letters, long descenders on S, word separation, etc.
children.family: Anglo-Saxon Scripts

children.title: Anglo-Saxon Round Miniscule and Anglo Caroline Miniscule
children.desc: Comes from Caroline script and Anglo-Saxon Square Miniscule (s. xi<sup>2</sup>).

children.title: Rapid Cursive
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Phase I
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Phase II
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Insular Half Uncial
children.desc: Text of the Lindisfarne Gospels. Round and vertically compressed because of adherence to head and base lines.
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Insular Hybrid Miniscule
children.desc: Similar to insular half-Uncial. The angle of the nib is the only difference. Also tends to seem overly-calligraphic.
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Insular Current
children.desc: Cursiva Currens
children.family: Insular Scripts

children.title: Caroline Miniscule (Littera Miniscula Carolina)
children.desc: (Most of Western Europe s. viii<sup>ex</sup> – xiii<sup>in</sup>).
children.family: Caroline

children.title: English Caroline Miniscule
children.desc: During King Edgar’s reign (957-975), Archbishop Dunstan, Bishop Aethelwold, and Bishop Oswald (all reformers) introduced Caroline Miniscule. English Caroline Miniscule is Caroline Miniscule with the addition of feet on minims. These feet are courtesy of Anglo-Saxon Miniscule.
children.family: Caroline

children.title: English Protogothic Book Script
children.desc: Sloping feet are constantly put on the minims. One can see the influence of Anglo-Saxon Miniscule.
children.family: Protogothic Script (Protogothic Script, Littera Miniscula Protogothica)

children.title: Continental Caroline Miniscule
children.desc: Uniform head and base lines, uniform ascenders and descenders, roundness, straight minims.
children.family: Caroline

children.title: Continental Protogothic Book Script
children.desc: Oval, compression, does not have the horizontal feet of English Caroline Miniscule.
children.family: Protogothic Script (Protogothic Script, Littera Miniscula Protogothica)

children.title: Documentaria
children.family: Protogothic Script (Protogothic Script, Littera Miniscula Protogothica)

children.title: Protogothic Documentary Script
children.desc: The speed and lengthened ascenders and descenders separate this from Protogothic Book Script. Thin pointed script and thicker pen script come together to create the litterae notabiliores.
children.family: Protogothic Script (Protogothic Script, Littera Miniscula Protogothica)

children.title: Protogothic Cursiva
children.family: Protogothic Script (Protogothic Script, Littera Miniscula Protogothica)

children.title: Protogothic Semicursiva
children.family: Protogothic Script (Protogothic Script, Littera Miniscula Protogothica)

children.title: English Cursive Book Script (Cursiva Anglicana or Anglicana Formata)
children.desc: Linking letters, loops, speed, decorated to impress. Used for English documentary scripts from s. xiii<sup>in</sup> to s. xiv)
children.family: Protogothic Script (Protogothic Script, Littera Miniscula Protogothica)

children.title: Secretary (Cursiva Media)
children.desc: Speed, but attention paid to elaborate calligraphy (ascenders are attenuated/look “clubbed”), pen flourishes are common, “horns” where strokes cross.
children.family: Gothic System of Scripts (s. xii<sup>ex</sup> – s. xvi)

children.title: Bastard Secretary
children.desc: Secretary features remain (clubbed ascenders, tall S, etc.) and are combined with a formal ductus which comes from Textualis.
children.family: Gothic System of Scripts (s. xii<sup>ex</sup> – s. xvi)

children.title: Batarde
children.desc: The highest grade of cursive and the greatest influence from Textualis. Secretary clubbed tall S, calligraphic,c keeps “prickleyness” of Secretary but has regularity and formality of Textualis.
children.family: Gothic System of Scripts (s. xii<sup>ex</sup> – s. xvi)

children.title: Hybrida
children.desc: Textualis script with several cursive letter forms. Distinguishable from Hybrida Cursiva/Hybrida Currens because it links letters without looping. Hybrida is closer to Textualis and Bastard Anglicana is closer to cursive.
children.family: Gothic System of Scripts (s. xii<sup>ex</sup> – s. xvi)

children.title: Bastard Anglicana (Anglicana Formata Hybrida)
children.desc: Round loops, letter forms of Anglicana and different forms of Textualis.
children.family: Gothic System of Scripts (s. xii<sup>ex</sup> – s. xvi)

children.title: Libraria (Littera Miniscula Protogothica Textualis Libraria Formata)
children.desc: Influenced by English Caroline s. xi<sup>ex</sup> – s. xii<sup>in</sup>.
children.family: Protogothic Script (Protogothic Script, Littera Miniscula Protogothica)

children.title: Gothic Textualis
children.desc: (s. xii<sup>ex</sup>). Lateral compression, compact, square.
children.family: Gothic System of Scripts (s. xii<sup>ex</sup> – s. xvi)

children.title: Textualis Precissa (Sine Pedibus)
children.desc: Minims end on the baseline (horizontal feet), most likely meant for display, compressed, space between script, etc.
children.family: Gothic System of Scripts (s. xii<sup>ex</sup> – s. xvi)

children.title: Textualis Quadrata (Fracta)
children.desc: Applied feet on the minims, regularity of script, space between script, etc.
children.family: Gothic System of Scripts (s. xii<sup>ex</sup> – s. xvi)

children.title: Textualis Semi Quadrata (Textura)
children.desc: Bottoms of the minims have applied foot every once in a while (like Textualis Quadrata).
children.family: GothicSystemofScripts(s.xii<sup>ex</sup>–s.xvi)

children.title: Littera Gothica Textualis Rotunda Italiana
children.desc: Like Textualis Semi Quadrata in ductus.
children.family: GothicSystemofScripts(s.xii<sup>ex</sup>–s.xvi)

children.title: Littera Glossarius Italiana
children.desc: Smaller version of Littera Gothica Textualis Rotunda Italiana used as gloss for it.
children.family: GothicSystemofScripts(s.xii<sup>ex</sup>–s.xvi)

children.title: Littera Gothica Textualis Rotunda Bononiensis
children.desc: Round caroline miniscule, lateral compression, no attenuation, etc.
children.family: GothicSystemofScripts(s.xii<sup>ex</sup>–s.xvi)

children.title: Textualis Rotunda (Textura)
children.desc: Does not have the applied feet, but is instead rounded off with an upwards curve of the pen, tends to laterally compress, etc.
children.family: GothicSystemofScripts(s.xii<sup>ex</sup>–s.xvi)

children.title: Semigothic Cursive (Littera Semigothica Cursiva)
children.desc: (s. xiv<sup>med</sup> – s. xvi<sup>med</sup>). The stage between Gothic scripts and Humanistic scripts (part of the purification of the Gothic script), breadth, straight-backed d. Used by Petrarch.
children.family: Humanistic Scripts

children.title: Humanistic Scripts
children.desc: (Florence before 1400). Roundness of aspect, separated letters, no abbreviations, etc.
children.family: Humanistic Scripts

children.title: Humanistic Book Script (Littera Humanistica Textualis, Littera Antiqua)
children.desc: (1402-1403) Used by Poggio Bracciolini. Caroline ligatures, some horizontal feet on minims, formal Caroline miniscule, etc.
children.family: Humanistic Scripts

children.title: Humanistic Cursive Book Script (Littera Humanistica Cursiva Libraria)
children.desc: (c. 1420) Invented by Niccolo Niccoli. A rapid version of Humanistic Textualis, takes some letter forms from Semigothic Cursive.
children.family: Humanistic Scripts

children.title: Humanistic Cursive (Littera Humanistica Cursiva, Cancellaresca)
children.desc: Adaptation of Gothic chancery hands – a combination of formal and cursive, used for documents, very calligraphic, elegant ascenders and descenders.
children.family: Humanistic Scripts
